body:

```

2015-05-22 23:13:46,703 FATAL Unable to register shutdown hook because JVM is shutting down.
```

I fixed the shutdown FATAL message in https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/1387

I'm in agreement with @gianm that if the process terminates due to signal a status of 0 is improper, and the return code should reflect a way to distinguish the signal used to terminate the task.

Adding a way to cleanly shutdown the server without relying on shutdown hooks is reasonable request though.

I suppose I can see both arguments making sense. @bjozet, openssh at least appears to [agree with you](http://openssh-bugs.mindrot.narkive.com/KfpPgIy6/bug-1879-new-after-sigterm-sshd-should-exit-with-exit-status-0). But, I don't see an easy way to influence the exit status of a java program that got SIGTERM'ed. You can register shutdown hooks to clean stuff up but you can't call System.exit or Runtime.exit from within those hooks.

Would it work to have your stop script touch a 'down' file so your monitoring script knows that the service is supposed to be down and isn't upset when it exits?

Bummer about the shutdown hooks.

Some questions:
- Does the code actually get called? It doesn't look like anything is injecting the QuietLoggerShutdown and I dunno if it will actually get instantiated.
- Is it possible to do something useful without needing a property? If not, how about emitting a warning on startup if the property isn't there, so people know they have a less than perfect setup?
- Is the dependency worth it or is it doing something really simple that we could just do ourselves?

I suspect I might be asking the wrong questions, making false assumptions, and possibly having missed something in the docs despite reading it more than once. 

What I want is a way to stop the druid processes gracefully, with a zero exit status. 

I was under the impression that SIGTERM's was the proper way to do it for druid; and it would initiate shutdown-hooks accordingly. If there is another way, such as, for example using a start/stop jar in the same manner as tomcat/catalina does, that's totally fine too! Sure I can work around issues as these in various ways, including touching 'down'-files here and there, but that also adds abstraction of process logic (from an operations point of view). 

Is there a proper way of stopping druid cleanly that I've totally overlooked?
@xvrl I will keep digging.

This generally LGTM.

One thing I noticed is that the benchmark is only testing a single pass without testing the "filtered" case.  It's not really accurate to say that it's a speedup without also adding various filtered test cases...

@cheddar agree, since we are benchmarking the storage array itself, we should probably update the benchmarks to include random access that will give us a better idea of performance impact when access is not sequential. Maybe we can do this as part of a benchmark improvement separate PR?

There has been an ongoing discussion on how to go forward with the pre and post merge deprecation.

I had created some changes which expressly get rid of pre and post merge and have persisted them in an mmx branch: https://github.com/metamx/druid/tree/deprecatePrePostMerge

The reason that things cannot simply be put in the merge method without significant changes is that the query path does not always hit the merge codepath, very notably in unit tests. Additionally, the Finalizing query runner requires some of the functionality in the current way of doing things. (possibly wrongly so)

Overall these are nice changes. I would like to see the constructor statements at the debug level if possible. Also if the push log statements could include the target directory that would be awesome. @drcrallen I updated the PR

Looking at what that class does, it basically just extends Log4j's ShutdownCallbackRegistry.  It's pretty difficult to do programmatic stuff to adjust the configuration of the log4j subsystem when you use properties files to initialize it.  We essentially need to set the system property before the log4j system is initialized.  

I believe it is initialized by the first call to `LoggerFactory.getLogger()` in `com.metamx.common.logging.Logger`.

So, if we were to actually add a static initializer there to set the system property for us, we would likely be able to register our own shutdown handler instead of having it use the internal one.

I would then recommend that we create our own ShutdownCallbackRegistry that
1. Registers with the normal JVM shutdown hook
2. On `start()` removes the JVM shutdown hook
3. On `close()`, if `start()` was called, shuts things down, if `start()` was not called, is a noop.

Aside from a nit about changes in one file just for the sake of making changes, this generally LGTM.

I looked into this a bit, and it might stem from assumptions of atomicity in the announcer. This was partially addressed in https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/1109 but not completely.

Curator does provide a `org.apache.curator.framework.recipes.nodes.PersistentEphemeralNode` which accomplishes exactly what the announcer intends to accomplish, but has two major distinctions:
1. There is no atomicity (all tasks are background tasks)
2. There is no compression like is currently enforced in the Announcer.

The Announcer probably needs re-written using the mechanism in PersistentEphemeralNode or similar.

Additionally, any place which uses the announcer probably needs assumptions of atomicity removed.

@bjozet : There is not currently a way to cleanly shutdown a general druid jvm and get an exit status of 0. In general the nodes are intended to never go down, and such having to shut one down is not normal course of action (Peons excluded).

I have some experimental Mesos work going on, and check for the return status of 143 as you have pointed out to verify that the task was killed.

I can see two kinds of shutdowns requested:
1. Shutdown now and forever. Meaning the instance never intends to come back up and should ensure that the items it is responsible for retain high availability before it shuts down
2. Restart. Meaning the instance expects to come back up with a few seconds of being shut down (due to upgrade or simply a reset of the JVM/heap)
@fjy  I'm waiting for comments

An example of this is if a VirtualBox instance is running which has port forwarding on `SOME_PORT`, then `SocketUtil` will not find it bound, but any attempts to connect to `localhost:SOME_PORT` can go through the port forward to the VM instead of to the desired bound port in the JVM

@fjy : the AnnouncerTest uses `org.apache.curator.test.KillSession#kill(org.apache.zookeeper.ZooKeeper, java.lang.String)`  to simulate ZK outages. 

Do you think that could help pinpoint this problem?
Is this related to https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/783 ?

For example, if you have some low cardinality columns, you can get their bitmaps to compress really well by grouping them together. High cardinality columns should have pretty sparse bitmaps anyways, so I wouldn't expect them to benefit much from grouping together.

Currently the concept of services is very very loose in druid and not as well defined as it could be. As an alternative to this, I believe we should have features defined by various servers, and announce those features independent of what cli was used to launch the node.

There was a problem at one time where requests were processing in the http thread pool instead of the processing thread pool. I thought there was a PR that fixed it but can't find it at this time. Is this still an issue?

@tarekrached at one time I had read a part that did, but I may have linked to the wrong part.

The index maker and merger behave differently.

I had a problem with the recompression where IndexMerger was ignoring the compression specified in the indexspec. I haven't been able to put in a unit test for it, but the IndexMaker implementation is the "safer" of the two (in the recompression case) as it takes an arbitrary QueryableIndex and goes row-by-row to rebuild the index.

Given that we have some extra IndexSpec stuff now, it would be worth adding in some more unit tests in IndexMergerTest to clarify what the behavior is overall, but for the purposes of this PR it should at least be added that IndexSpec is properly honored in IndexMerger (instead of just queryable)
Can we add in a check for `io.druid.segment.column.Column#TIME_COLUMN_NAME` to make sure someone doesn't do something silly?

@fjy  if you don't want to add a check I'm fine with that because it is very unlikely, but if you want to be super safe it should be added as a checked column name.

LGTM

@cheddar : Doing such a thing in the Logger would also be a multi-system intrusion of log4j instead of slf4j abstraction.

We cannot rely on the JVM shutdown hook because they are fired essentially randomly. We have to be able to specify that the logger shutdown hook runs after the Lifecycle shutdown, which is not the case if both are simply shutdown hooks (unless you know some magic you would like to share :) )

The problem happens because we end up building a transient groupBy query that adds all
agg.getRequiredColumns() from original outer query which would have same name.
